title: Gene Munster Talks Mag 7 Growth, Microsoft | Bloomberg Talks

rawLines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts,
radio, news.
Joining us now to get out to the tech
earnings and the tech space, Deep Water
Asset Management, Gene Monster. Can't
say enough about Jean's commitment to
Bloomberg surveillance in combination
with Dan Ies. Eyes Monster Eyes we saw
on July 4th with Jean. Thank you for
that commitment to doing that uh
program.
Got it. Love it. Gene, I brought up
Microsoft, which I never look at, and
they got a they're modeling 12 13%
revenue growth. Do you have a conviction
on Mag 7 blended revenue growth, does it
sustain or is there a direction to it?
Well, I can tell you what the numbers
are that basically if you look at
everything with the exception of Nvidia,
the street expectations for this year is
13% growth and uh maybe as expected a
similar growth rate for 2026. Now,
typically when you see rising numbers,
uh the comps get more difficult and the
street anticipates a deceleration in
growth. And what we're seeing is kind of
the opposite. This is kind of a a rare
chapter. My sense is that next year
calendar 26 is going to surprise to the
upside and I just want to caution is
when I the markets at all-time highs. I
think that that kind of gets people a
little bit more enthusiastic and I'm I'm
backing out what the market's doing. I
just want to kind of zero in on what the
fundamentals are, right? And the bottom
line is that these companies are just
fundamentally having more success in in
squeezing juice out of their existing
business and just adding additional
spice to their growth. And so, uh, Tom,
I feel really good about how, uh, these
companies are going to play out. The one
I would mention that I'm less
optimistic, you mentioned Microsoft. Uh,
that is one that I don't think has the
dynamic upside that a lot of the other
big tech companies do. Using that as a
model, you had a COVID recovery, you had
a 2022 pause and then up up and away
with the Yardeni and Compora October
2022 bottom. Gene Monster, do you as a
tech guy, do you extrapolate that trend
from the autumn of 2022?
I
I do. I I think that when you uh there's
going to be es and flows in terms of
kind of optimism and pessh skepticism
skepticism uh the liberation day back in
April optimism where we're at now but if
you if you step back and look at the
broader trend over the next three years
let's say I think that this is going to
uh continue to be a bull market. I think
it's going to go materially higher and
ultimately I think it's going to end in
a in a bursting of a bubble. Uh, and the
reason why I mentioned that kind of that
that that that rough edge of of kind of
how this plays out is that if I'm right
about what the next three years look
like and we get just across the board
optimism. I mean, uh, levels that, uh, I
think are hard to kind of comprehend, I
think that ultimately there probably is
some sort of bubble bursting. But Tom,
to answer your question, I think that,
you know, we're we're very optimistic.
Deep Water, we are about 70% of our
investments are AI related. Wow.
And I sleep well at night. Jean, you you
said you were maybe a little bit
cautious on Microsoft. I look at the ANR
function for Microsoft. 65 buys, seven
holds, zero sells. What's your current
view of Microsoft here?
You just have better places to invest
and uh they've steady revenue. There is
a lot of that predictability which is
attractive. Uh I just maybe to give some
context to why the stock is working.
That piece is attractive. And second is
Microsoft has probably been the most
forwardthinking company when it comes to
using AI to save cost. They've talked
about this $500 million in annual
savings just in terms of coding moving
that over to the machine. And so I think
that investors are are expecting some
margin expansion. So I think that you
know that's the reason why it's moving
up. The reason why I'm uh just think
there are better places to be is that
ultimately the uh the upside to the
numbers if you look at across the rest
of the mag 7 I think there's just more
upside to you know Microsoft for example
is not going to grow at 20%. might grow
at 14 and a.5% whereas you have a
company like Apple surprisingly the
street's looking for mid-s singledigit
growth next year and you could see 8%
growth.
Gene, I was in the acclaimed Bloomberg
food court the other day looking at the
Red Sox box scores. I don't know if
you're aware, Gene, but the Red Sox have
won 10 in a row and one of our fancy
artificial intelligence people walked up
to me and said, "You know, Tom, you need
a brief." So, I got briefed. Do you
parse a difference between
chat GBT Google Gemini? Help me here.
Anthropic perplexity is something. Are
are these all equal things, Gene
Monster, or for our listeners and
viewers, do we need to learn nuances of
them?
Well, the the answer is it's nuance. And
this is something we're actually working
on a a bigger project right now. We're
going through and testing these
different models. And there are uh
there's like broadly accepted testing
benchmarking uh like chatbot arena for
example which is is widely recognized
but there's a lot of gamification in
terms of how the companies uh go up
against those those those those
benchmarks and then there's just uh the
coding side how well there's a code and
then there's just like the real world
like does it give you the answer you're
looking for and it turns out that each
of these models with the exception of
llama llama is pretty weak and so but if
you look at the other four primary
models uh they all have kind of
different strengths. And so, uh,
ultimately is that, um, think of AI as
more of like a personality is that the
world isn't going to be centered on one
personality. We wouldn't want that. And
so, each of these models has a slightly
different personality and slightly
different strengths. And so that's what
we are seeing is if you're going to say
what's like the best model kind of
putting everything all together it's
it's probably uh open AI uh GPT today
and then Grock and and Gemini kind of
close behind.
So Gene today the news is on the chip
side uh the US government says I don't
Nvidia AMD they can start sending some
of these advanced AI chips to China.
What's the backstory there? What stocks
are trading up on this news?
Well, it's big news obviously for Nvidia
and they talked three months ago about
this impact being a negative 15% to the
overall growth. So if you think about
the street numbers maybe just to Paul to
kind of zero in on what's going on with
Nvidia is company 3 months ago says we
can't sell these H20s to China uh and
that's going to cost us 15% of our
revenue. Um the reason why that the
street numbers are not going to go up by
15% today is twofold. Number one is the
40 analysts that cover Nvidia. About
eight of them had anticipated that these
curbs be released uh uh in this current
quarter. And so you saw some of the
analysts already expecting this
announcement. And then separately is
that uh this is good news. It's good
news for Nvidia, but like the whole
geopolitical conversation around how
chips play into rare minerals and all
that that hasn't been solved. And if one
thing we've learned over the last three
months is that you really can't take one
development in a day and extrapolate it
over the next couple years. So that's
why the stock's up 5% today, not 15%.
Quickly, let's do that with Apple. Why
not? Okay. Gene Monster on Apple. Are
they going to surprise people with a
plus+ here in the announcement?
Uh, you know, as far as like the
geopolitical side um like announcements
there, I I I don't know if anything's
going to happen there. I can say this is
that if you look at the mag 7 and look
at where is the the likely most upside
in the September quarter so pretty
narrow near-term focused Apple's at the
top of the list. The street's looking
for flat revenue growth in the September
quarter. They're contin they're going to
benefit from that huge 37% growth back
in 2021. Those upgrades are going to be
coming in, right?
It's it's not flashy. It's not AI. But
in terms of going into this print and
the commentary about the September
quarter, I think Apple's going to uh
show well.
Jean, thanks for the brief. Gene Monster
with deep water and technologist.

Got it. Love it. Gene, I brought up Microsoft, which I never look at, and they got a they're modeling 12, 13% revenue growth. Do you have a conviction on Mag 7 blended revenue growth, does it sustain or is there a direction to it?
